title: Erdős #673: Sum of Consecutive Divisor Ratios
description: For G(n) = Σ dᵢ/dᵢ₊₁ (consecutive divisor ratios), does G(n) → ∞ for almost all n? What is the asymptotic formula for Σ G(n)? Solved: Tao gave bounds τ(n/m)/m ≤ G(n) ≤ τ(n).

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Terence Tao, Gérald Tenenbaum

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem about the function G(n) = Σ dᵢ/dᵢ₊₁ summing consecutive divisor ratios. The first question (G(n) → ∞ for almost all n) is trivial. Terence Tao established the key bounds. Erdős and Tenenbaum proved G(n)/τ(n) has a continuous distribution function.
overview.problemStatement: Let 1 = d₁ < d₂ < ... < d_τ(n) = n be the divisors of n. Define G(n) = Σᵢ dᵢ/dᵢ₊₁. (1) Does G(n) → ∞ for almost all n? (2) Find an asymptotic formula for Σ_{n≤X} G(n).
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize G(n) as a sum over consecutive divisor ratios, establish Tao's bounds (τ(n/m)/m ≤ G(n) ≤ τ(n)), prove asymptotic behavior (average → ∞), and formalize the Erdős-Tenenbaum distribution result.
keyInsights: G(n) = sum of consecutive divisor ratios dᵢ/dᵢ₊₁
Tao: τ(n/m)/m ≤ G(n) ≤ τ(n) for any divisor m of n
For even n: τ(n)/4 ≤ G(n) ≤ τ(n)
Σ_{n≤X} G(n) ~ c X log X for some constant c

sections.title: Asymptotic Behavior
sections.summary: Average tends to infinity, almost all n

sections.title: Multiplicative Properties
sections.summary: G is not multiplicative, coprime relations

sections.title: Asymptotic Formula

sections.title: Connection to τ(n)
sections.summary: G and τ have similar average behavior

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #673 on consecutive divisor ratios. The first question (G(n) → ∞ almost always) is trivial. The key results are Tao's bounds relating G(n) to τ(n), and the Erdős-Tenenbaum theorem that G(n)/τ(n) has a continuous distribution function.
conclusion.implications: Understanding G(n) provides insight into the structure of divisor sequences. The bounds show G(n) behaves similarly to τ(n) on average, connecting to classical results in analytic number theory.
openQuestions: What is the exact constant c in Σ G(n) ~ c X log X?
What is the explicit form of the distribution function for G(n)/τ(n)?
How does G(n) behave for specific number families (primes, prime powers, squarefree)?
